Metalloporphyrin-based multifunctional catalysts for one-pot assisted Tandem reaction Renaldo Marcos da Silva Junior Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Investigation Writing – original draft Everton Henrique dos Santos Methodology Formal analysis Investigation Visualization Writing – original draft Shirley Nakagaki Conceptualization Resources Project administration Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing ⁎ Laboratório de Bioinorgânica e Catálise, Departamento de Química, Centro Politécnico, Universidade Federal do Paraná (UFPR), 81531990, Curitiba/PR, Brazil Laboratório de Bioinorgânica e Catálise Departamento de Química Centro Politécnico Universidade Federal do Paraná (UFPR) 81531990 Curitiba/PR Brazil Laboratório de Bioinorgânica e Catálise, Departamento de Química, Centro Politécnico, Universidade Federal do Paraná (UFPR), 81531990, Curitiba/PR, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. Multicomponent and multifunctional solid catalysts based on the tetra-anionic manganese(III)porphyrin Na4[Mn(TDFSPP)(Oac)] (MnP) immobilized on inorganic supports composed of silica/WO3/layered material were idealized, prepared and investigated as catalyst solids for heterogeneous process in one-pot cyclohexane oxidation to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone followed by ketalization of the cyclohexanone carbonyl group to dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal with methanol. We expected that the MnP would catalyze cyclohexane oxidation, and that the acid sites of the silica/WO3/layered material would assist cyclohexanone/methanol ketalization. After establishing the optimal conditions for the single organic reactions separately, we proposed the proof-of-concept one-pot assisted Tandem reaction of cyclohexane oxidation to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone with PhIO catalyzed by silica/WO3/layered material/MnP and ketalization of the cyclohexanone carbonyl groups with methanol to obtain dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal as final product. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Porphyrin Biomimetic catalyst Cytochrome p-450 Oxidation Ketalization Heterogeneous catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Inspired by natural catalytic systems such as Cytochrome P-450 (CP450) [1–3], researchers have investigated synthetic metalloporphyrins (MPs) as catalysts in several organic reactions [4–7], including oxidation [2,3,8], condensation [9], esterification [10], and CO2 cycloaddition [11], among others, in which the MP mimics the biological functions of CP450 [12,13]. To make MPs even more robust, the structure of the tetrapyrrolic macrocycle can be improved (often through costly synthetic processes) by adding substituents that provide them with more resistance to oxidation processes [13–15]. Another way to improve the robustness of MPs is to immobilize them on solid supports [2,3,16–32] or to heterogenize them as MOF solids [33–35] or polymers like PIMs or POMs [36–39]. Immobilization prevents side reactions that could deactivate the MP and facilitates MP recovery and reuse, so it is a good strategy to adopt when designing a multifunctional and long-life catalyst for different purposes, ultimately leading to more sustainable chemical processes [40–42]. Furthermore, the microenvironment generated by immobilization of the MP frequently allows selectivity to be modulated by using specific supports, mimicking what happens between the prosthetic group and the protein in nature. Selectivity will depend on fine tuning of the chemical, morphological, and textural properties of the solid support and the MP [25,43,44]. Silica is one of the most used solid supports for immobilizing MPs. It can be functionalized with different groups, allowing anionic, cationic, and neutral species to be immobilized via electrostatic interaction, covalent binding, and even trapping inside the silica matrix [25,26,45]. Additionally, silica matrixes generally present high thermal and mechanical stability and, depending on morphology, large surface area (up to 800 m2 g−1 as observed for mesoporous silicas [25,46]). They may even display intrinsic catalytic activity especially due to the presence of silanol groups [47]. For instance, Ucoski et al. [25] performed n-hexane oxidation by using different SBA-15 mesoporous silica matrixes containing a manganese(III) porphyrin as catalyst and observed unusual selectivity for 1-hexanol. This was probably associated with immobilization of the manganese(III) porphyrin into the silica mesopores, so that the resulting steric effects favored n-hexane oxidation at position 1. Natural and synthetic layered solids (e.g., LDH – layered double hydroxide and LHS – layered hydroxysalt) have recently been investigated as support for immobilizing MPs [17,43,48–51]. These materials are composed of layers of metal ions and hydroxy groups stacked up along the Z axis; the layers contain species intercalated between them, to keep electroneutrality [52]. These layered materials bear positive or negative charges over the layers, which allow them to interact electrostatically with anionic or cationic molecules, respectively [53]. They also present potential intrinsic catalytic Lewis and Bronsted-Lowry sites due to their layered composition [54–56], which can be attenuated by layer exfoliation [57]. For example, when MPs are investigated as catalysts for alkane oxidation, selectivity toward the alcohol is typically observed [25,58]. However, our group has recently shown [17,43] that, depending on how the MP interacts with an LHS, selectivity changes: ketone formation is favored, which could resemble the effects of the different axial ligands in CP450 and heme-haloperoxidases (H-HPO) [1–3]. The polymorphic phases of tungsten trioxide (WO3) have potential application as support for MPs and other catalytic species. WO3 has a negative charge-rich surface and notable properties. Like silica, it displays high thermal and mechanical stability as well as excellent textural properties [59–61]. Moreover, WO3 is an N-type semiconductor [62] whose band gap has suitable energy [63] for catalyzing diverse reactions [64,65]. It also presents Bronsted-Lowry (-W-O-H) and Lewis (-W6+) acid sites, so it can be employed as catalyst in esterification and transesterification reactions [66,67]. Therefore, WO3 is promising for designing multifunctional catalysts. Considering the stability and the diverse mechanisms through which MP-based solids can act, and depending on the catalytic reaction and the chemical characteristics of the support, supported MPs can be investigated in one-pot sequential reactions involving one or more mechanisms (domino or cascade and Tandem, respectively) [16,68]. This approach allows the potential of the MP to be explored even further and generates less waste. Nevertheless, applying MPs as catalysts in sequential reactions is an under-explored research topic, as reviewed in [16]. Beyzavi et al. [33] investigated an iron(III) porphyrin-based metal organic framework (MOF) in which the porphyrin moieties were connected by hafnium nodes containing two iron ions. Because this MOF is rich in Lewis acid sites due to the presence of iron and hafnium ions, the authors investigated it in a Tandem reaction of olefin epoxidation catalyzed by the iron(III) porphyrin, as a CP450 mimic, and ring-opening catalyzed by hafnium and iron ions, as Lewis acid catalysts. At 60 °C and under 5 atm O2 pressure, this sequential reaction led to full regioselective conversion to the azidohydrin product after 10 h. Yu et al. [34] prepared a manganese(III) porphyrin MOF containing Zr6 cluster nodes (MOF-545) and functionalized it with imidazolium bromide for Tandem reaction of olefin epoxidation and CO2 gas cycloaddition to the resulting epoxides, to generate cyclic carbonates; O2 and isobutyraldehyde were used as oxidants. After carrying out the proposed sequential reaction at 70 °C for 10 h, the authors observed 100% conversion to the desired final product. Selectivity was as high as 96.4%. Such results could be a consequence of the presence of bromide anions in the prepared multifunctional catalyst—such anions may have acted as cocatalyst during cycloaddition. In addition, solids containing immobilized MPs have been investigated as catalysts in sequential reactions. Dias et al. [69] prepared hybrid manganese(III) and chromium(III) porphyrin-containing core@shell magnetite/silica solids and investigated them as catalysts in alkene epoxidation followed by CO2 cycloaddition, to obtain cyclic carbonates with conversion as high as 100% and selectivity for the desired product under mild conditions. These solids constituted a good example of multifunctional solids: manganese(III) porphyrins usually afford good epoxidation yields; chromium(III) porphyrins are good Lewis acids; and the support allows for easier and clean recovery of the catalyst. We have recently reviewed other examples of MP-based solids employed in sequential reactions [16]. Despite the scarcity of works in this field, these examples show the potential development of multicomponent and multifunctional MP-based solids, which bear different sites with the intrinsic catalytic activity of each individual component or even new sites resulting from the synergistic effect of the interaction among the components. These solids can be investigated as catalysts in one-pot sequential reactions involving a unique or distinct mechanisms performed by a single solid containing the MP. This approach can promote a more robust bioinspired chemical catalytic transformation system in which raw reactants are converted to more complex and valuable chemicals. In this way, solvent and reactant wastes can be avoided, contributing to proper achievement of the goals of green chemistry. In this scenario, here we have developed multicomponent and multifunctional solid catalysts based on the tetra-anionic manganese(III)porphyrin Na4[Mn(TDFSPP)(Oac)] (MnP) immobilized on inorganic supports composed of silica/WO3/layered material and investigated their catalytic activity in one-pot cyclohexane oxidation to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone with PhIO followed by ketalization of the cyclohexanone carbonyl group to dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal with methanol. We expected that the MnP would catalyze cyclohexane oxidation, and that the acid sites of the silica/WO3/layered material would assist cyclohexanone/methanol ketalization. After establishing the optimal conditions for the single organic reactions separately, we proposed the proof-of-concept one-pot assisted Tandem reaction of cyclohexane oxidation to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone with PhIO catalyzed by silica/WO3/layered material/MnP and ketalization of the cyclohexanone carbonyl groups with methanol, to obtain dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal as final product. To our knowledge, there are no reports of the use of solids based on metalloporphyrins immobilized on different supports that can act as a multifunctional catalyst for a Tandem reaction as proposed in this work. Scheme 1 illustrates this conceptual sequential catalytic reaction. Experimental section All the reagents and solvents used in this work were purchased from Aldrich, Merck, Fluka, or Synth with analytical purity grade. Iodosylbenzene (PhIO) was prepared by hydrolysis of iodosylbenzene diacetate, according to the method described by Sharefkin and Saltzmann [70]. The PhIO purity of 93% was confirmed by iodometric titration [70]. Preparation of the porphyrins and manganese(III) porphyrin The neutral porphyrin ligand [H2(TDFPP)] [5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,6-difluorophenyl)porphyrin] was prepared and purified according to the literature [43,71]. The anionic porphyrin Na4[H2(TDFSPP)] {[5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,6-difluoro-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrin] tetrasodium} was prepared by sulfonation of [H2(TDFPP)] [15,19] (see experimental details in Supplementary Information). The anionic manganese(III) porphyrin Na4[Mn(TDFSPP)(Oac)] (designated MnP hereafter) (Fig. 1 ) was prepared by Na4[H2(TDFSPP)] metalation with manganese(II) acetate salt (Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O, or Mn(Oac)2) (Oac = acetate anion) [21,72]. For this purpose, Mn(Oac)2 (0.420 g, 1.71 mmol) was added to a solution containing Na4[H2(TDFSPP)] (0.100 g, 0.086 mmol) in acetic acid and was kept under magnetic stirring (200 - 250 rpm) at 120 °C for 24 h. The metalation reaction was monitored by TLC and UVVIS. The resulting solution was dried in a rotary evaporator, and the MnP (Fig. 1) was purified by column chromatography on Shepadex 25 G; water was used as eluent. After drying in a rotary evaporator, a brown-green solid was obtained and stored at 4 °C (0.730 g, 0.568 mmol, yield of 66%). UVVIS spectrum bands λmax (nm, water, concentration solution ca. 1 10−5 mol L): 324, 368, 392, 458 (Soret band, ε = 8.4 × 104 cm·mol−1·L−1), and 552. The IR spectrum showed similar bands to the bands of Na4[H2(TDFSPP)] except for the presence of the C-O stretch bands of the acetate group at 1541 and 1384 cm−1 and the absence of the shoulder band at 3313 cm−1 characteristics of N-H stretching. Preparation of solid supports Preparation of silica by the sol–gel method Silica (S) was prepared by the sol–gel method [22,24,73]. In a 250-mL Erlenmeyer flask, aqueous ammonia (6.9 mL) was added, followed by ethanol (35.5 mL) and tetraethyl-ortho-silicate was added dropwise (TEOS, 3.1 mL). A white dispersion was formed and kept under magnetic stirring (250 - 300 rpm) at 30 °C for 24 h. The dispersion was centrifuged at 3500 rpm, and the solid was washed three times with 20-mL portions of deionized water, centrifuged, and dried at 100 °C. The prepared solid was stored at room temperature (0.858 g, yield of 99%). Silica (S) was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) coupled to energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). Preparation of SBA-15 mesoporous silica SBA-15 mesoporous silica (MS) was prepared according to the method described by Zhao [24,46]. In a 1000 mL Erlenmeyer flask, Pluronic P123 copolymer (25 g) was dissolved in aqueous hydrochloric acid solution (2 mol L−1, 815 mL), and TEOS (57 mL) was added dropwise. A white dispersion was formed and kept under magnetic stirring (250 - 300 rpm) at 35 °C for 24 h. After that, the solid dispersion was aged in an oven at 80 °C for 24 h and centrifuged at 3500 rpm, and the solid was washed three times with 20 mL portions of deionized water and calcined in a muffle oven at 550 °C. MS solid was characterized by powder XRD, TEM, SEM, EDS and FTIR (13.0 g, yield of 89%). Preparation of silica/WO3 S/WO3 and MS/WO3 solids were prepared by the in situ impregnation method of tungstic acid (H2WO4) over silica (S or MS) and calcination [66,74]. For this purpose, in a 100 mL Erlenmeyer flask, S or MS (0.40 g), sodium tungstate (0.095 mol L−1, 8 mL), and hydrochloric acid (6 mol L−1, 8 mL) were mixed, to give a yellow dispersion, which was kept under magnetic stirring (250 - 300 rpm) at 20 °C for 3 h. The dispersion was centrifuged at 3500 rpm, and the resulting white solid was washed three times with 20 mL portions of deionized water and calcined in a muffle oven at 500 °C for 5 h. The prepared solid (S/WO3 and MS/WO3) were stored at room temperature and characterized by powder XRD, TEM, SEM, EDS and FTIR (S/WO3: 0.50 g, yield of 57%, and MS/WO3: 0.31 g, yield of 50%). Preparation of silica/WO3/ZHN S/WO3/ZHN and MS/WO3/ZHN solids, where ZHN = zinc hydroxide nitrate layered material, were prepared by in situ ZHN synthesis on silica/WO3; the precipitation method of ZHN preparation was followed [17,75]. In a 100 mL Erlenmeyer flask, S/WO3 or MS/WO3 (0.20 g) was mixed with zinc nitrate (3 × 10−3 mol L−1, 6.6 mL), and aqueous ammonia solution (3.5 mol L−1) was added dropwise until pH 6.74 was achieved. The resulting dispersion was kept under magnetic stirring (250 - 300 rpm) at 25 °C for 3 h, and the dispersion was centrifuged at 3500 rpm. The resulting white solid (S/WO3/ZHN or MS/WO3/ZHN) was washed three times with 20-mL portions of deionized water and dried at 25 °C for 8 h. The prepared solids (S/WO3/ZHN and MS/WO3/ZHN) were stored at room temperature and characterized by powder XRD, TEM, SEM, EDS and FTIR (S/WO3/ZHN: 0.56 g, and MS/WO3/ZHN: 0.66 g). Preparation of silica/WO3/LDH S/WO3/LDH and MS/WO3/LDH solids, where LDH = Zn/Al layered double hydroxide, were prepared by coating S/WO3 or MS/WO3 with LDH [21,76]. Initially, in a 500 mL Erlenmeyer flask, LDH was prepared by coprecipitation reaction between aluminum chloride (0.05 mol L−1, 100 mL) and zinc chloride (0.20 mol L−1, 100 mL) at pH 10. The resulting LDH dispersion was centrifuged at 3500 rpm, and the resulting white solid was washed three times with 20-mL portions of deionized water and dried at 25 °C for 8 h. Thereafter, in a mortar, LDH (0.30 g) and S/WO3 or MS/WO3 (0.30 g) were added and manually macerated for 0.5 h. The resulting solid was dispersed in distilled water (100 mL) in an ultrasonic bath at 25 °C for 3 h, washed three times with 20-mL portions of deionized water, centrifuged at 3500 rpm, and dried at 25 °C for 8 h. The prepared solid (S/WO3/LDH and MS/WO3/LDH) were stored at room temperature and characterized by powder XRD, TEM, SEM, EDS and FTIR (S/WO3/LDH: 0.60 g, and MS/WO3/LDH: 0.60 g) Immobilization of MnP on silica/WO3/layered material The MnP was immobilized on S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, or MS/WO3/LDH solid according to a formerly described methodology [17,26,27,43]. In a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask, the MnP (ca. 50 mL of 2.0 × 10−5 mol/L methanol solution (Soret band at 460 nm, ε = 6.0 × 104 cm·mol−1·L−1) and the support (0.150 g of S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, or MS/WO3/LDH) were kept under magnetic stirring (250 - 300 rpm) at 35 °C for 6 h (light orange colored mixture). The immobilized MnP was separated from the suspension by centrifugation (4000 rpm for 5 min) and exhaustively washed with methanol until the electronic spectrum of the supernatant did not exhibit the typical absorption bands of the MnP that leached during the washing procedure. The obtained light orange solids were named S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP and were dried in an oven at 60 °C for two days. The solution resulting from the washing of each immobilized MnP was quantitatively analyzed by UVVIS spectroscopy for indirect determination of the amount of the MnP that was immobilized on each support (loading values of mol of MnP per mass (g) of support). All the prepared solids were stored at 4 °C. S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP were solid was characterized by powder XRD, TEM, SEM, EDS and FTIR and ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (UVVIS). Catalytic reactions S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP solids were investigated as catalyst in three different single organic reactions: cyclooctene or cyclohexane oxidation with PhIO, as oxidant, and cyclohexanone ketalization with methanol, as ketalizing agent. S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP were also investigated as catalyst in a one-pot reaction involving two steps, cyclohexane oxidation with PhIO, to generate cyclohexanone, followed by cyclohexanone ketalization with methanol, to obtain dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal. Cyclooctene or cyclohexane oxidation The following general method was used in the oxidation reactions [25,43]. To a 2.0-mL amber glass vial with polypropylene screw-cap and soft white PTFE/silicone septa, a certain mass of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP (3 – 10 mg), a certain mass of PhIO as oxidant (MnP/PhIO molar ratio of 1:20 or 1:200), acetonitrile as solvent (500 μL), and a certain volume of the substrate (ca. 10 μL of cyclooctene or cyclohexane, MnP/substrate molar ratio of 1:2000) were added (PhIO concentration = 9.0 × 10−3 mol/L for 1:200 MnP/PhIO molar ratio and 9.0 × 10−4 mol/L for 1:20 MnP/PhIO molar ratio). The reaction was kept under magnetic stirring (200 - 250 rpm) at 25 °C for 1 h in a dark chamber under argon atmosphere. Next, 100 μL of a saturated acetonitrile solution of sodium sulfite was added to the reaction mixture, to eliminate excess of PhIO. Then, the reaction dispersion was centrifuged, to separate the immobilized MnP, and the resulting supernatant was added to a 2.0-mL volumetric flask. The catalyst solid was washed three times with 100-μL portions of acetonitrile, to extract any remaining reaction products. All the extracts were combined in the same 2.0-mL volumetric flask and to an aliquot of 500 μL of the solution was added 10 μL of acetonitrile solution of n-octanol (internal standard, 1 × 10−2 mol/L). The resulting solution was analyzed in duplicate by gas chromatography, to quantify the products (Figure S1, Supplementary information). The yields of the products were calculated on the basis of the starting PhIO, and all the reactions were performed in at least triplicate. Control reactions were performed in the same way by using S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, or MS/WO3/LDH, the substrate, and PhIO; or only the substrate and PhIO. Homogeneous catalysis was also performed by using the MnP instead of immobilized MnP under the same reaction conditions. Cyclohexanone ketalization The following general method was used in the ketalization reactions [77]: to a 2.0-mL amber glass vial with polypropylene screw-cap and soft white PTFE/silicone septa, S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP solid (15 mg), cyclohexanone (10 μL), and methanol (1 mL) were added, and the reaction was kept under magnetic stirring (200 - 250 rpm) at 55 °C for 2 h in an open to light chamber. Next, the reaction suspension was centrifuged, to separate the immobilized MnP, and the resulting supernatant was added to a 2.0 mL volumetric flask. The immobilized MnP was washed three times with 100-μL portions of acetonitrile, to extract any remaining products. All the extracts were combined in the same 2.0-mL volumetric flask and to an aliquot of 500 μL of the solution was added 10 μL of acetonitrile solution of n-octanol (internal standard, 1 × 10−2 mol/L). The resulting solution was analyzed in duplicate by gas chromatography, to quantify the products. All the reactions were performed in at least triplicate. Control reactions were performed in the same way by using S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, or MS/WO3/LDH, the substrate cyclohexanone, and methanol; or only the substrate cyclohexanone and methanol. Homogeneous catalysis was also performed by using the MnP instead of immobilized MnP under the same reaction conditions. One-pot assisted Tandem sequential reaction Cyclohexane oxidation with PhIO followed by cyclohexanone ketalization with methanol was carried out. Briefly, to a 2.0-mL amber glass vial with polypropylene screw-cap and soft white PTFE/silicone septa, S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP solid, PhIO (MnP/PhIO molar ratio of 1:20), acetonitrile (as solvent, 500 μL), and cyclohexane (MnP/substrate molar ratio of 1:2000) were added. The reaction was kept under magnetic stirring (200 - 250 rpm) at 25 °C for 1 h in a dark chamber under argon atmosphere. Then, methanol (1 mL) was added to the flask (using a syringe), and the reaction was kept under magnetic stirring (200 - 250 rpm) at 55 °C for 2 h in an open to light chamber. Next, the reaction suspension was centrifuged, to separate the immobilized MnP, and the resulting supernatant was added to a 2.0-mL volumetric flask. Then, the immobilized MnP was washed three times with 100-μL portions of acetonitrile, to extract any remaining products. All the extracts were combined in the 2.0-mL same volumetric flask into which the standard was also added, and the resulting solution was analyzed in duplicate by gas chromatography, to quantify the products. n-Octanol was used as internal standard. All the reactions were performed in at least triplicate. Control reactions were performed in the same way by using S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, or MS/WO3/LDH solid and the reactants or only the reactants. Catalyst reuse tests were also carried out with the most promising solids. The catalysts recovered at the end of the first use were washed with methanol and acetonitrile, dried at 60 °C, and reused in further reactions, adopting the same procedure described before. Characterization and apparatus Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Shimadzu XRD-7000 diffractometer operating at 30 kV and 40 mA (Cu Kα radiation λ = 1.5418 Å) with a monochromator (scan rate of 2° min−1); 2θ ranged from 3 to 80° FTIR spectra were recorded on a Bomen Michelson MB-102 spectrophotometer between 400 and 4000 cm−1, in KBr pellets. KBr was crushed with a small amount of the solid sample, and the spectra were collected with a resolution of 2 cm−1 and an accumulation of 64 scans. Raman spectra were recorded on a Witec Alpha 300R spectrophotometer between 0 and 1000 cm−1, using a laser (532 nm), to obtain spectra with a resolution of 0.02 cm−1. UVVIS spectra were recorded between 200 and 800 nm on an HP 8452A and a Varian Cary 100 spectrophotometer. Cells with path length of 1.0 cm or 0.5 cm were employed. Qualitative spectra of the solid samples were also recorded by diffuse reflectance. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out with a JEOL-JEM 1200 microscope operating at 120 kV. The TEM samples were prepared by dispersion in ethanol at room temperature. A drop of the supernatant dispersion was then placed onto a carbon film supported by a copper grid. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted on a Tescan VEGA3 LMU device with a tension of 10 KV. A small amount of the sample was placed on a sample holder, which was submitted to a gold metallization process. 1H NMR spectra (200.13 MHz) were acquired at 298 K on a Bruker AVANCE 200 NMR spectrometer operating at 4.7 T and equipped with a 5-mm tetranuclear direct detection probe (1H, 13C, 19F, and 31P). Methanol-d4 (CD3OD) was supplied by Aldrich. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained on a NOVA 1000 analyzer (Quantachrome). The samples were degassed under vacuum at 90 °C for 6 h and analyzed in liquid nitrogen. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were obtained in a relative pressure range from 0.05 to 0.99, and the specific surface area was calculated by using the multipoint Brunauer-Emmet-Teller method (B.E.T.), with relative pressure ranging from 0.05 to 0.3. For all the support solids obtained, the tungsten, zinc and manganese concentrations were quantitatively analyzed by optical emission spectroscopy with inductively coupled plasma (ICP-OES). The measurements were carried out with an iCAP 6500 from Thermo Scientific, using diluted solutions prepared from the stock solution of the solid (ca. 15 mg) dissolved in a 5% (v/v) HNO3 solution (50 mL). The analyses were performed at least in duplicates and average values were used. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were accomplished on an EPR Bruker EMX microX spectrometer (frequency of 9.5 GHz) at room temperature in the perpendicular microwave polarization X-band. All the products from the oxidation and ketalization reactions were quantified on an Agilent 6850 gas chromatograph (flame ionization detector) equipped with a 30-m-long DB-WAX capillary column with 0.25-mm internal diameter (J&W Scientific). Results and discussion Characterization of free-base porphyrin and manganese(III) porphyrin We characterized the neutral free-base porphyrin, [H2(TDFPP)], the tetra-anionic free-base porphyrin, Na4[H2(TDFSPP)], and the complex resulting from Na4[H2(TDFSPP)] metalation with manganese(III), Na4[Mn(TDFSPP)(Oac)] or simply MnP, by UVVIS spectroscopy, which revealed the typical spectra of porphyrin ligands and manganese(III) porphyrins (Fig. 2 ). The UVVIS spectra of [H2(TDFPP)] and Na4[H2(TDFSPP)] (Fig. 2a and b, respectively) displayed the characteristic Soret band of the porphyrin ring around 412 nm and four bands between 500 and 650 nm, attributed to the Q bands of the porphyrin ligand [13,21,26,43,78,79]. When Na4[H2(TDFSPP)] was metalated with manganese(III), the Soret band shifted to higher wavelength (460 nm, Fig. 2c) because symmetry changing from free-base ligand to MnP complex which also led to the number of Q bands between 500 and 600 nm decrease from four to two. Moreover, the LMCT bands at 328, 372, and 394 nm, typical of manganese(III) porphyrins, emerged [80–82]. Figs. 3 a,b, and c show the FTIR spectra of [H2(TDFPP)], Na4[H2(TDFSPP)], and MnP, respectively. The FTIR spectrum of Na4[H2(TDFSPP)] displayed bands at 1132 and 621 cm−1, due to the S-O vibration modes, confirming sulfonation. The band around 1650 cm−1 in the FTIR spectra of [H2(TDFPP)] and Na4[H2(TDFSPP)], related to the N-H angular vibration mode, indicated that the pyrrolic nitrogen atoms in the free-base porphyrins were protonated. This band disappeared in the FTIR spectrum of the MnP. Besides that, the FTIR spectrum of the MnP presented two sets of bands, around 1665–1316 cm−1 (∆ = 349 cm−1) and 1575–1396 cm−1 (∆ = 179 cm−1), related to the O-C=O asymmetric and symmetric axial deformation modes. These sets of bands resulted from two coordination modes of the acetate anion–monodentated and as a bridge between two MnPs, respectively. These results suggested that the acetate anion was present as an axial ligand in the MnP [43,81,83,84]. Figure S2 (Supplementary information) contains the 1H NMR spectrum of [H2(TDFPP)]. The spectrum presented chemical shifts between 7.3 and 7.5 ppm and between 7.7 and 7.9 ppm, due to eight meta and four para hydrogen atoms of the meso phenylic group substituents in the free-base porphyrin, respectively. The eight β-pyrrolic hydrogen atoms led to a chemical shift between 8.8 and 9.0 ppm. Figure S3 (Supplementary information) shows the 1H NMR spectrum of Na4[H2(TDFSPP)] [15], which displayed the chemical shifts due to four meta (7.4–7.7 ppm) and four para (8.2 –8.6 ppm) hydrogen atoms of the meso phenylic group substituents of the free-base porphyrin and eight β-pyrrolic hydrogen atoms (8.8–9.2 ppm). The reduction from eight to four meta hydrogen atoms was expected: sulfonation caused four meta hydrogen atoms of the phenylic substituents to be substituted for four sulfonate groups [15,43]. Characterization of silica/WO3/layered material We prepared silica (S or MS)/WO3/layered material (ZHN or LDH) for further immobilization of the MnP. Although immobilization facilitates recovery and reuse of the MnP, the components of the immobilized MnP catalyst may not be innocent and might in fact contribute to the catalytic activity, leading to a multifunctional catalyst with Bronsted-Lowry and Lewis acid sites. Such multifunctionality allows various one-pot sequential catalytic processes to be investigated [16]. Basically, we prepared MnP immobilized on supports consisting of a) silica or mesoporous silica, b) WO3, and c) layered material (zinc hydroxide nitrate (ZHN) or layered double hydroxide (LDH)). We chose silica and WO3 because this combination acts as a good catalyst—WO3 provides tungsten(V) and W-O-H species for Lewis and Bronsted-Lowry acid site-dependent reactions, respectively [66]. The third component, ZHN or LDH, bears positive charges, allowing the tetra-anionic MnP to be immobilized via electrostatic interaction (Scheme 2 ) [18,27,31,43,85]. We prepared amorphous spherical silica (S) by the hydrolytic sol–gel method reported by Stober et al. [73]. We synthesized mesoporous silica SBA-15 (MS) by the methodology described by Zhao et al. [46], which corresponds to the hydrolytic sol–gel method catalyzed by acid in the presence of the copolymer Pluronic P123. This copolymer acted as a surfactant, directing structure growth. We obtained S/WO3 and MS/WO3 by synthesizing WO3 in the presence of S and MS in situ, respectively. Initially, we prepared H2WO4 over the surface of S or MS by following the methodology reported by Nogueira et al. [74], by reacting sodium tungstate with hydrochloric acid. Then, we converted H2WO4 to WO3 by calcination at 500 °C [74]. We characterized S, MS, H2WO4, WO3, S/H2WO4, MS/H2WO4, S/WO3, and MS/WO3 solids by FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 4 ). All the FTIR spectra displayed a broad band between 3700 and 3100 cm−1 and a band at 1600 cm−1 related to the vibration modes of H-O-H and O-H of adsorbed water molecules. The FTIR spectra of S and MS presented the typical bands of the silica structure, namely a band in the 1300–1000 cm−1 region (attributed to the axial deformation mode of Si-O-Si), a band at 945 cm−1 (due to the axial deformation mode of Si-OH), and a band at 800 cm−1 (associated with the angular deformation mode of siloxane groups) [23–25,86]. In turn, the FTIR spectra of H2WO4, WO3, S/H2WO4, MS/H2WO4, S/WO3, and MS/WO3 displayed bands in the 1000–600 cm−1 region due to the W-O-W and W = O of the H2WO4 and WO3 groups [74]. In addition to the aforementioned bands assigned to the silica and tungsten-based components, S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH (Figure S4c, d, e, and f, respectively, Supplementary material) presented specific bands. The FTIR spectra of S/WO3/ZHN and MS/WO3/ZHN displayed a band at 1385 cm−1, ascribed to the N-O vibration mode of intercalated nitrate anions, whereas the FTIR spectra of S/WO3/LDH and MS/WO3/LDH presented a band at 1370 cm−1, assigned to the carbonate anion intercalated in the LDH interlayer structure [21,50,58,76,87–89]. We characterized S, MS, H2WO4, WO3, S/H2WO4, MS/H2WO4, S/WO3, and MS/WO3 by XRD (Fig. 5 ). The diffractograms of S and MS (Fig. 5a and b, respectively) showed the typical halo in the 2θ range of 15 - 30° This halo was due to the absence of long-range organization of the crystalline units, which is expected for silicas obtained by the sol–gel method, a process that favors the formation of solids without crystalline organization [23–25,86]. The diffractogram of H2WO4 displayed peaks at 2θ 12.8, 25.6, and 38.4° (Fig. 5c), characteristic of its layered crystalline organization [61]. Thermal treatment at 500 °C for 5 h converted H2WO4 to WO3, whose diffractogram exhibited peaks at 2θ 23.2, 23.6, and 24.4°, typical of this family of oxide and corresponding to the (001), (020), and (200) planes, respectively. This pattern is related to the orthorhombic crystalline phase, which originated as a consequence of the temperature employed during thermal treatment [61,66]. Besides that, the diffractogram suggested full conversion of H2WO4 to the WO3 phase (Fig. 5d). The diffractograms of S/H2WO4 and MS/H2WO4 (Fig. 5e and f, respectively) and S/WO3 and MS/WO3 (Fig. 5g and h, respectively) presented the peaks observed for the individual components, suggesting that the phases of each component were present in the support. Nonetheless, a more attentive analysis of the diffractograms of S/WO3 and MS/WO3 in the 2θ range of 23–25° (23.26° (001), 23.68° (020), and 24.41° (200)) (detached part in Fig. 5) revealed broader and less intense peaks than the peaks in the diffractogram of WO3, which presented an orthorhombic phase. These divergences indicated a blend of the orthorhombic and monoclinic WO3 phases in S/WO3 and MS/WO3 [61,66,90]. We also characterized ZHN, LDH, S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH by XRD (Fig. 6 ). The diffractogram of ZHN displayed the typical high and intense diffraction peak of the ZHN phase (Zn5(OH)8(NO3)2·2H2O) at 2θ 9.0°, assigned to the (200) plane. This peak was due to the layer stacking direction and the presence of interlayer hydrated nitrate anions [18,75,91]. We also verified the characteristic peaks at 2θ 18.4, 34.6, 35.4, 46.8, and 47.4°, related to the (400), (221), (710), (10 0 0), and (−712) planes, respectively (Fig. 6a). The diffractogram of LDH (Fig. 6b) had peaks at 2θ 11.3, 22.6, and 33.9°, related to the (003), (006), and (009) planes, respectively. These peaks are commonly observed in the diffractogram of such material and refer to layers stacked along the Z-axis. The basal distance calculated by using Bragg's Law equation showed the presence of intercalated carbonate anions [76,87–89]. The diffractograms of S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH (Fig. 6c,d,e, and f, respectively) corresponded to a combination of the diffraction patterns of the individual components of the supports, namely S or MS, WO3, and ZHN or LDH [18,75,76,87–89,91], with less intense peaks. This indicated that ZHN or LDH was present in a delaminated or exfoliated form, which can improve the catalytic activity due to greater surface availability in these supports [57]. The TEM and SEM images of ZHN (Fig. 7 a and c, respectively) showed stacked rectangular and few delaminated platelets as commonly observed for layered hydroxide salts [18,75,91]. As for the TEM and SEM images of LDH (Fig. 7b and d, respectively), they presented typical hexagonal and delaminated stacked platelets, as expected for this family of layered material [18,75,76,87–89,91]. Furthermore, these materials were pure: we detected no solids with different morphologies (e.g., zinc or aluminum oxide). The TEM and SEM images in Fig. 8 a and g, respectively, showed that S had spherical and well-dispersed particles, with diameter around 285 nm, a typical result for silica obtained by the sol–gel method. Fig. 8b and h showed that MS had homogeneous and well-defined worm-like morphology. The characteristic porous structure expected for SBA-15 was also evident. These observations agreed with the use of the surfactant Pluronic P123, as template, to obtain MS [46,92–94]. The TEM and SEM images of S/H2WO4 and MS/H2WO4 (Fig. 8c,d,i, and j) showed the presence of spherical (S) and worm-like (MS) morphology, respectively, and small delaminated plates, due to H2WO4, which interacted with the S or MS particles. The original morphology of S and MS was preserved. Such observations indicated that S or MS and H2WO4 were mixed. The TEM and SEM images of S/H2WO4 and MS/H2WO4 after thermal treatment, designated S/WO3 and MS/WO3, respectively, are presented in Fig. 8e,f,k, and l. The structures of S and MS remained intact after thermal treatment, whilst the H2WO4 plates were converted to spheroid particles and are related to WO3, as expected [74], suggesting a chemical interaction between S or MS and WO3 [66]. The TEM and SEM images in Fig. 9 suggested the presence of ZHN or LDH in S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH. The TEM images evidenced the presence of wiper-like platelets of layered material (ZHN or LDH) over S/WO3 and MS/WO3 [25,27,43,66], confirming that S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH were successfully prepared. In addition, the interaction among the components was relatively strong given that there was no segregation. The Raman spectra of S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH (Figure S5, Supplementary material) showed low intense bands at 93 and 135 cm−1, assigned to the W-W bond in the crystal lattice of WO3 [95–97], as well as two bands, at 273 and 330 cm−1, attributed to the axial and angular deformation of O-W-O, respectively. Bands ascribed to polytungstate (WO6) were present at 719 and 810 cm−1. The more this set of bands shifted to higher frequency, the greater the amount of tungstate species and the higher the dehydration degree [95–97]. Moreover, the Raman spectrum of WO3 prepared alone showed bands due to the monoclinic phase at 80, 126, 269, 322, 710, and 801 cm−1 [95]. As for the Raman spectrum of WO3 prepared on S and MS, these bands shifted to higher frequency (96, 138, 276, 331, 721, and 801 cm−1), which is associated with the triclinic WO3 phase. Even though the bands at 106, 348, and 924 cm−1 are attributed to the orthorhombic WO3 phase [97], monoclinic and triclinic are the major WO3 phases (Table S1, Supplementary information) [95–97]. Figure S6 (Supplementary information) illustrates the electron paramagnetic resonance spectra (EPR) of S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH, which presented a set of broad signals in the 2000–3000 G region (g = 2.58), suggesting the presence of W5+ or W3+ in bulk-like solids [95–97]. This result indicated that the crystal lattice of WO3 became distorted upon interaction with SiO2, which may have modified the WO3 coordination sphere (e.g., reduction of diamagnetic W6+ (typically observed in WO3 prepared alone) to the paramagnetic oxidation states W5+ and W3+) [95–98]. Figure S7 (Supplementary information) shows the isotherms obtained from BET surface analyses [99]. S and S/WO3 (Figure S7a), which are slightly porous, presented type-III isotherm, corroborating the morphologies of amorphous silica and tungsten oxide. On the other hand, MS and MS/WO3 presented type-IV isotherm, typical of mesoporous support. They also presented H1 hysteresis, indicating uniformly distributed and ordered pores. ZHN, LDH, S/WO3/ZHN, and S/WO3/LDH presented type-III isotherm and H3 hysteresis (Figure S7c), indicating slightly porous supports with slit-like morphology, as expected. However, MS/WO3/ZHN and MS/WO3/LDH had type-II isotherms, in contrast with previous results obtained for SBA-15. They also displayed two hysteresis, H2 and H1, indicating little defined porous morphology and blocked pores due to the presence of WO3 and ZHN or LDH. Table 1 (Figure S7, Supplementary information) lists the surface area (SBET) values of S, MS, ZHN, LDH, S/WO3, MS/WO3, S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH measured through the BET method. The SBET values agreed with literature values [25,43,66]. MS had greater area than S mainly due to the ordered mesopores in the structure of MS. There were no changes on the surface of S/WO3 or MS/WO3, suggesting that WO3 was randomly deposited over the surface of silica. The SBET value decreased when ZHN or LDH was deposited on S/WO3 and MS/WO3, suggesting that the layered materials may have obstructed the silica pores [25,43,66]. S/WO3/LDH and MS/WO3/LDH had greater SBET than S/WO3/ZHN and MS/WO3/ZHN, which could be a consequence of the higher degree of particle delamination of LDH compared to ZHN. We conducted ICP-OES analysis to quantify the concentration of W, Zn, and Mn in S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH (see Table S2, Supplementary information), which contained an average of 9% in mass of W. In other words, every 100 mg of the support contained 11.35 mg of WO3 (loading of 0.49 mmol of WO3 per gram of silica/WO3), suggesting that the supports consisted mostly of SiO2. Besides, the supports contained an average of 15% in mass of Zn and less than 0.1% in mass of Mn (as impurity from the Zn and Al salts used to prepare the layered materials), as also observed by EPR analysis (Figure S6, Supplementary information). Characterization of silica/WO3/layered material/MnP The supports containing ZHN or LDH are expected to have positive residual charges over their structures. For this reason, we expected that the tetra-anionic MnP would interact electrostatically with these residual positive charges [21,24,43]. Table 2 reports the MnP loading on S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH. We qualitatively calculated the MnP loading as a function of the concentration of the MnP in the supernatant analyzed by UVVIS spectroscopy after the immobilization process [24,25]. The MnP loading values resembled the values observed for solids where MPs interact electrostatically with the support [17,18,21,27,31,76]. The MnP could not be immobilized on S/WO3 or MS/WO3, without layered material, because these supports did not bear positive charges for electrostatic interaction with the MnP, thereby confirming the importance of the layered material for immobilization of the MnP. MS/WO3/ZHN and MS/WO3/LDH provided higher percentage of MnP immobilization, probably because these supports had greater extent of delamination than S/WO3/ZHN and S/WO3/LDH. In addition, some MnP may have been trapped inside the MS mesopores, leading to higher percentage of MnP immobilization on MS/WO3/ZHN and MS/WO3/LDH [25]. In terms of layered material, the supports containing LDH gave higher percentage of MnP immobilization, as expected, because LDH had greater surface area and more delaminated particles than ZHN, so the LDH-containing supports presented greater positive charge density [17,21,43]. Figure S8 (Supplementary information) shows the FTIR spectra of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP. Verifying the presence of immobilized MnP on the supports was difficult because we employed a small amount of the MnP during the immobilization process [27–32]. The diffractograms of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP (Figure S9, Supplementary information) presented the typical pattern of the corresponding supports. The basal peaks due to ZHN and LDH kept the same 2θ values as compared to the supports without immobilized MnP. This suggested that the MnP was immobilized on the surface of the support, and that no MnP intercalated between the ZHN or LDH layers [27–32]. We also characterized S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP by UVVIS diffuse reflectance (Fig. 10 ). The spectra displayed the characteristic MnP Soret band at 464 nm and a Q band at 560 nm, indicating that the MnP was immobilized on the supports (Fig. 10a-d correspond to the spectra of S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH, while Fig. 10e-h correspond to the spectra of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP). The Soret band of the MnP at 461 nm was slightly bathochromic shifted after immobilization (464 nm), suggesting that the macrocycle structure can be distorted upon interaction with the support [43]. Table 1 shows the SBET values of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP calculated by BET analyses. S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP had slightly greater surface area than the parent support without immobilized MnP. Therefore, the immobilization process may have favored fragmentation and exfoliation of the layered material on the support, unclogging the silica pores (the adsorption and desorption isotherms are presented in Figure S10 (Supplementary information) [21,25]. Catalytic investigation of the immobilized MnP in single organic reactions We evaluated the catalytic activity of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP solids in two single organic reactions. We used cyclooctene or cyclohexane as substrate and PhIO as an oxygen transfer agent (oxidant model [6,13,14,18-20,43]), which should give cyclooctene oxide or cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone as the main product(s), respectively. Cyclooctene oxidation allows the efficiency of the catalyst to be evaluated, whereas cyclohexane oxidation allows the efficiency and selectivity of the catalyst to be assessed. In addition, we evaluated the catalytic efficiency of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP in cyclohexanone ketalization with methanol. Cyclooctene oxidation We investigated cyclooctene oxidation catalyzed by S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP by using a MnP/PhIO/cyclooctene molar ratio of 1:20:2000 or 1:200:2000. The catalytic activity of all solids was first evaluated in the oxidation of this diagnostic substrate of catalytic activity since this substrate is easily oxidized, leading to cis-cyclooctene oxide as sole product when MP is used as catalyst [31]. Given that the MnP was well dispersed on the supports, and that the MnP loading on the supports was low, we intended to observe how the amount of oxidant influenced the yield of product (see Table 3 and Figure S11, Supplementary information). The control reaction (Table 3, entry 1) gave low yield of cyclooctene oxide (less than 10%), irrespective of the MnP/PhIO/cyclooctene molar ratio. In the presence of S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, or MS/WO3/LDH (without immobilized MnP), the yield of cyclooctene oxide was also less than 10% (Table 3, entries 2 to 5). On the other hand, when we used S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP as catalyst, the yield of cyclooctene oxide ranged from 40 to 90% (Table 3, entries 7 to 10), suggesting that the MnP acted as the main catalytic species in cyclooctene oxidation, whilst S or MS, WO3, and ZHN or LDH acted only as components of the MnP support, preventing the catalyst from being deactivated by side reactions [22,24,25,78]. We had not expected the low yield of cyclooctene oxide obtained in the reaction catalyzed by the MnP in homogenous medium (Table 3, entry 6) [22,24,25]. This result could be understood as a consequence of the low solubility of the MnP in the reaction solvent (acetonitrile), which reduced the interaction between the catalyst and the reactants, a problem that was overcome when we employed S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP [22,24,25,78]. There were differences in the yield of cyclooctene oxide depending on the composition of the support. S/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP (Table 3, entries 7 and 8) gave higher yield of cyclooctene oxide than S/WO3/ZHN/MnP and MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP (Table 3, entries 9 and 10). This could be related to the higher MnP loading on S/WO3/LDH and MS/WO3/LDH than on S/WO3/ZHN and MS/WO3/ZHN. This allowed us to use a smaller mass of S/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP (≈4 mg) compared to S/WO3/ZHN/MnP and MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP (≈10 mg) during the reactions, which must have resulted in better dispersion of S/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP and provided more efficient interaction of the MnP with the reactants. The type of silica (S or MS) also affected the performance of the MnP (Table 3, entries 7 to 10). S/WO3/LDH/MnP performed better than MS/WO3/LDH/MnP, but MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP performed better than S/WO3/ZHN/MnP. S/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP had greater degree of layered material exfoliation, which must have caused greater dispersion of the MnP over the layered material, favoring the catalytic activity while avoiding dimerization or occlusion of the MnP. The MnP/PhIO/cyclooctene molar ratio did not influence the yield of cyclooctene oxide, so we chose the 1:20:2000 molar ratio to evaluate the recovery and reuse of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP in cyclooctene oxidation (Table S3, Supplementary material). We recovered and reused the S or MS/WO3/layered material/MnP five times (Table S3). The catalytic activity of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP was maintained even after the fifth reuse reaction, but the yield of product decreased slightly. This decrease could be associated with leaching of the MnP during the recycling process [74]; however, we did not detect any MnP in the washing solutions as analyzed by UVVIS spectroscopy suggesting that some destruction of the immobilized complex structure is also possible. Cyclohexane oxidation We also investigated S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP solid as catalyst in the oxidation of a saturated hydrocarbon. We selected cyclohexane as substrate and PhIO as oxidant and evaluated the MnP/PhIO/cyclohexane molar ratios of 1:20:2000 and 1:200:2000 (Table 4 and Figure S12, Supplementary information). We assessed the efficiency and selectivity of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP with respect to the formation of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone. In homogeneous medium (MnP in solution) (Table 4, entry 1), we achieved yield of approximately 14% for cyclohexanol and 1.8% for cyclohexanone. Despite the great selectivity for cyclohexanol, the use of the MnP as catalyst in solution gave lower yield of products than the use of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP as catalyst (Table 4, entries 2 to 5; the yield of cyclohexanol ranged from 32 to 44%, and the yield of cyclohexanone ranged from 8 to 11%, with high selectivity for the alcohol – about almost four times more alcohol than ketone). The better results achieved with S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP could be attributed to the stability of the MnP: immobilization protected the MnP against deactivation mechanisms (dimerization and self-destruction, which could inactivate the catalytic species). Additionally, immobilization must have overcome the solubilization issues of the tetra-anionic MnP in the reaction medium (acetonitrile) [43]. The results in Table 4 (entries 2 to 5) also showed that the MnP/PhIO/cyclohexane molar ratio of 1:200:2000 gave lower yield of products than the MnP/PhIO/cyclohexane molar ratio of 1:20:2000. High excess of oxidant may have deactivated the MnP through oxidative destruction or even obstructed the MnP. Indeed, during homogeneous catalysis at a MnP/PhIO/cyclohexane molar ratio of 1:200:2000 (Table 4, entry 1), high excess of PhIO made the MnP more susceptible to oxidative destruction mainly due to the partial solubility of the MnP in the reaction medium. Therefore, immobilization of the MnP protected it against self-destruction. For example, the reaction catalyzed by MS/WO3/LDH/MnP (Table 4, entry 3) gave 11% yield of products even in the presence of high excess oxidant. The control reaction without MnP in solution (Table 4, entry 6) or on the support (Table 4, entries 7 to 17) gave lower yields of product (less than 14%) than the reactions catalyzed by the MnP (free MnP in solution or immobilized MnP, Table 4, entries 1 to 5), which indicated the major role played by the MnP in cyclohexane oxidation. Solid supports such as amorphous silica, SBA-15 mesoporous silica, tungsten oxide, LDH, and LHS (e.g. HNZ) do not act as good catalysts for cyclohexane oxidation [18,24,25,31], leading to very low yields of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone, about 5%. Compared to the results we achieved with S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP, the results we obtained in the control reactions showed higher selectivity for cyclohexanone. The results obtained during cyclohexane oxidation catalyzed by S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP did not reveal large differences that could be attributed to the chemical/morphological or textural properties of the support (Table 4, entries 2 to 5), except for S/WO3/LDH/MnP (Table 4, entry 2). The higher yield achieved with S/WO3/LDH/MnP could be associated with LDH delamination on the support, which may have favored better dispersion of the immobilized MnP and reduced the possibility of bimolecular interactions that could inactivate the MnP [27,100]. The images in Fig. 9a and e showed greater LDH delamination over the S/WO3 particles, which may have contributed to better immobilization and distribution of the MnP over the entire support [21]. The images of MS/WO3/ZHN (Fig. 9d and h) revealed that this support did not show good ZHN delamination over the MS/WO3 particles. However, we observed fragmented ZHN crystallites over the SBA-15 silica worm-like particles in MS/WO3/ZHN, so this support probably also contained better dispersed MnP over the entire structure, preventing the MnP from being deactivated by side reactions. The better dispersion of the MnP may also have increased the interaction of PhIO and cyclohexane with the MnP, resulting in better catalytic performance (Table 4, entry 5) [25]. S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP continued to provide good yield of products even after five reuse reactions, albeit with a small decrease (Table S4, Supplementary information). This decrease was possibly due to leaching of the MnP during the recycling process, as observed when we used cyclooctene as substrate (Table S3, Supplementary information). Moreover, during the reuse experiments, more cyclohexanone was produced along the process (Table S4, entries 4 to 7). This suggested that some leaching of the MnP took place (or destruction of some quantity of the complex), so participation of the MnP catalytic intermediate was minimized, while the supports, which were more selective for cyclohexanone than the MnP, gained a more prominent role in the reuse reactions, favoring the ketone product and/or even alcohol reoxidation to ketone [43]. Cyclohexanone ketalization We evaluated S, MS, WO3, ZHN, LDH, S/WO3, MS/WO3, S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, MS/WO3/LDH, S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP solid as catalyst in cyclohexanone ketalization with methanol. In this reaction (proof-of-concept reaction), a Lewis or a Bronsted-Lorry acid catalyst is expected to activate the cyclohexanone carbonyl, allowing a nucleophilic attack by methanol, to form dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal. Recently, Santos et al. [101] prepared acid catalysts based on silica/WO3 for transesterification reactions. They used these catalysts in the transesterification of soybean oil to the respective esters and obtained yields of up to 93%. Peruzzolo et al. [66] also prepared a solid catalyst based on mesoporous silica/WO3 and used it to catalyze palmitic acid esterification with methanol to methyl palmitate and achieved yields of up to 99%. Therefore, we expected that the supports S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/ZHN, S/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/LDH could act as acid catalyst in cyclohexanone ketalization (Figure S13, Supplementary information). The control reaction, conducted in the absence of MnP or support (Table 5 , entry 1, and Figure S14, Supplementary information), did not give any dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal. This suggested that, in the experimental conditions proposed for the ketalization reaction, the reaction did not occur without the presence of an adequate acid catalyst. In the presence of the solids LDH or S, there was no production of dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal, either, so they were inefficient as acid catalyst for this reaction. In the presence of MS, WO3, or ZHN, the yield of ketal was under 5%, suggesting that alone they may present some acid sites that could act as catalysts for the ketalization reaction. However, the amount or strength of acid sites was insufficient to give more expressive yields (Table 5, entries 3, 4, and 6, respectively) [102]. We obtained better yields of ketal in the presence of S/WO3 or MS/WO3: almost 12% and 48%, respectively (Table 5, entries 7 and 10, respectively). This reinforced the good efficiency of WO3 in this kind of reaction, as reported in the literature [66,101]. However, MS may have positively influenced WO3 through a different attaching mode given that S/WO3 gave four times lower yield of ketal than MS/WO3. To understand these results better, we performed a qualitative experiment to get some insight into the acidity of S, MS, WO3, S/WO3, and MS/WO3: we followed the adsorption of pyridine on S, MS, WO3, S/WO3, and MS/WO3 by FTIR analysis (Figure S15, Supplementary information). Pyridine did not interact with S or WO3, we did not observe the bands at 1445, 1490, 1540, and 1598 cm−1 due to the chemisorption of pyridine on S or WO3, which suggested that they did not present a large number of acid sites (Figure S15). On the other hand, for S/WO3 and MS/WO3, we detected the bands at 1445 and 1598 cm−1, associated with coordination of pyridine to Lewis acid sites, and the bands at 1540 and 1540 cm−1, related to coordination of pyridine to Bronsted sites. In other words, pyridine interacted with the acid sites available in S/WO3 and MS/WO3. The acid sites may have been due to the Bronsted acidity of the functional groups (W-OH) in WO3 or the Lewis acidity of tungsten in two oxidation states (W6+ and W5+) in the WO3 moiety. These oxidation states may have originated at the interface between silica and WO3 due to the change of the crystalline phase from orthorhombic to monoclinic, as indicated by Peruzzolo et al. [66]. In addition, the smaller the particle size of WO3, the better dispersion of tungsten over the surface of silica, and the greater the availability of acid sites in the structure, as suggested by Vrbková et al. [103]. We observed higher yield of ketal in the presence of S/WO3/ZHN (Table 5, entry 9) compared to S/WO3, suggesting that ZHN could have suitable sites for catalyzing the reaction, and that these sites were probably based on tetrahedral Zn ions. In the pyridine adsorption experiment (Figure S15), we had verified that pyridine interacted with ZHN, probably through Bronsted (-Zn-OH) and Lewis (-Zn-) acid sites. Indeed, the greater the amount of Zn ions in the layered material, the more pronounced the Lewis acidity, as reported by Kenyon et al. [104]. We obtained a different result in the presence of S/WO3/LDH (Table 5, entry 8), though: it afforded lower yield of ketal than S/WO3. LDH probably caused blockage, hampering mass transfer of the reactants, or inactivating the active catalytic sites of WO3 (Table 5, entry 8). Besides, LDH contained only octahedral Zn ion sites, so it did not contribute with sites that could act as acid sites. Wu et al. [105] stated that LDH can only act as a good acid catalyst if its structure contains oxygen vacancies—a coordinative site becomes available, providing LDH with Lewis acidity. This commonly occurs when nitrate is the intercalating anion that coordinates to the metal in the LDH layer. If the metal is labile enough, it can release nitrate, generating an oxygen vacancy and providing Lewis acidity [105]. Nevertheless, this probably did not happen with LDH in this work because it contained intercalated carbonate (Figure S15, Supplementary information). Blockage must also have occurred in MS/WO3/ZHN and MS/WO3/LDH (Table 5, entries 11 and 12), but the positive catalytic effect of ZHN minimized the negative effect of blockage (Table 5, entry 9 in comparison to 12) Acid sites present on solid catalysts facilitate ketalization of aldehydes and ketones, and solid catalysts with strong and abundant acid sites give higher yield of ketal than solid catalysts with relatively weak acidity [77,106,107]. The catalytic results presented in Table 5 suggested that S/WO3/ZHN presented greater concentration of Lewis acid sites and increased acid site strength, as confirmed by the pyridine adsorption experiment. When we evaluated the MnP (homogeneous catalysis), S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP as catalyst, we obtained very low yield of ketal (Table 5, entries 13 to 17), which indicated that immobilization of the MnP probably blocked the WO3 catalytic sites, and that the MnP was an inefficient catalyst for ketalization. Recently, Ferreira et al. [79] demonstrated the ability of FeP to act as an acid catalyst in benzaldehyde ketalization. However, the inability of the MnP to catalyze this same reaction confirmed that it is not a good Lewis acid catalyst. Similar result in a ketalization reaction were found using acids catalysts as aluminum doped porous silica [108,109], tungsten doped porous silica [110], zeolites [111], MOFs [112]. One-pot assisted Tandem reaction of cyclohexane oxidation with PhIO and cyclohexanone ketalization with methanol On the basis of the results we obtained in the single organic reactions (Table 4 and 5), we performed a proof-of-concept one-pot assisted Tandem reaction of cyclohexane oxidation to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone with PhIO and ketalization of the cyclohexanone carbonyl groups with methanol catalyzed by silica/WO3/layered material/MnP, to obtain dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal as final product (Scheme 3 ). Table S5 (Supplementary information) summarizes the results. First, we conducted cyclohexane oxidation at 55 °C for 3 h (Table S5) instead of using room temperature for 1 h, because these were the conditions that we had tested for cyclohexanone ketalization. Under the former conditions, the yields of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone were practically the same as those obtained for the reactions carried out at room temperature for 1 h (Table 4). Interestingly, for MS/WO3/LDH/MnP, the yield of the products increased from 43.4% at room temperature for 1 h (Table 4, entry 3) to 53.4% (Table S5, entry 2), one of the best catalyst performances under this new condition. Besides that, there was lower selectivity for the alcohol when we increased the reaction temperature and time. These results were promising because cyclohexanone is the target substrate for ketalization in the desired one-pot assisted Tandem reaction. Higher production of cyclohexanone under this new reaction condition may also have been a consequence of reoxidation of cyclohexane to the respective ketone under longer reaction time and higher temperature [17,43,113]. After we investigated cyclohexane oxidation with PhIO at 55 °C for 3 h, we tested S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, S/WO3/LDH/MnP, or MS/WO3/LDH/MnP as catalyst in the complete proof-of-concept one-pot assisted Tandem reaction (cyclohexane oxidation with PhIO followed by cyclohexanone ketalization with methanol) (Scheme 3). Table S6, Part II (Supplementary information) lists the results as percentage of cyclohexane conversion to cyclohexanol (A), cyclohexanone (K), and ketal (Ke) based on the initial amount of cyclohexane used in each reaction. For comparison purposes, we recalculated the results of cyclohexane oxidation to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone presented in Table S5 in terms of percentage of cyclohexane conversion (instead of percent yield based on PhIO as presented in Table S5) and included them in Table S6, Part I. Fig. 11 also illustrates the comparative results presented in Table S6. In the first step of the one-pot sequential reaction (cyclohexane oxidation with PhIO), we obtained good cyclohexane conversion yields (%) for cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone (Fig. 11, Part II), but with some differences regarding the results we obtained in the single cyclohexane oxidation reaction (Fig. 11, Part I). In the latter case (Fig. 11, Part I), the total yield of products (A + K)% decreased in the order S/WO3/LDH/MnP > S/WO3/ZHN/MnP > MS/WO3/LDH/MnP > MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, whereas in the cyclohexane oxidation step of the sequential reaction the total yield decreased in the order MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP > MS/WO3/LDH/MnP > S/WO3/LDH/MnP > S/WO3/ZHN/MnP (Fig. 11, Part II). These results suggested that the production of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone in the single cyclohexane oxidation reaction was better when the reaction was catalyzed by S/WO3/LDH/MnP and S/WO3/ZHN/MnP, containing amorphous silica, whilst the production of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone in the cyclohexane oxidation step of the sequential reaction was better when the reaction was catalyzed by MS/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, containing mesoporous silica. Apart from the catalytic differences caused by the presence of S or MS in the composition of the catalyst (that are not easy to understand), MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP, containing ZHN, gave the best result for cyclohexane oxidation in the sequential reaction, which differed from the results obtained in the single cyclohexane oxidation reaction. The arrangement of ZHN in MS/WO3 as well as its exfoliation/delamination may have positively affected the catalytic activity of the MnP under the conditions of the cyclohexane oxidation step of the sequential reaction, in contrast to what we had observed under the conditions used in the single cyclohexane oxidation reaction presented in Table 4. In addition, S/WO3/ZHN/MnP and MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP displayed high selectivity for cyclohexanol, higher than 70%, which we had also observed in the single cyclohexane oxidation reaction (Fig. 11, Part I). As for S/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP, alcohol/ketone selectivity changed under conditions of the cyclohexane oxidation step of the sequential reaction: about 60% selectivity for the alcohol versus 40% selectivity for the ketone (Fig. 11, Part II). S/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP did not present activity in the second step of the sequential reaction; that is, there was no cyclohexanone conversion to ketal (Table S6, entry 1 and 2, Part II and Fig. 11 Part II). These results were expected because S/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP were not active in the single cyclohexanone ketalization reaction (Table 5), either, giving yield of ketal lower than 1% (Table 5, entries 14 and 15). S/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP performed well in cyclohexane oxidation because the MnP underlay the oxidation catalysis. Nevertheless, unlike the FeP reported by Ferreira et al. [79], the MnP in S/WO3/LDH/MnP and MS/WO3/LDH/MnP did not present enough Lewis acidity to catalyze cyclohexanone ketalization. S/WO3/ZHN/MnP and MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP catalyzed cyclohexanone ketalization in the second step of the sequential reaction (Table S6, entry 3 and 4, Part II, and Fig. 11, Part II). These results were expected because S/WO3/ZHN/MnP and MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP also presented better catalytic performance in the single ketalization reaction (Table 5, entries 16 and 17), confirming that the presence of ZHN positive affected the acidity of S/WO3/ZHN/MnP and MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP positively, regardless of the type of silica (S or MS) (Table 5). The control experiments conducted in the absence of the MnP or support did not produce any ketal because the sequential reaction requires the presence of the MnP and acid sites. Finally, it was observed that the solids S/WO3/ZHN/MnP and MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP continued to provide good yield of products even after two reuse reactions, however with a small decrease (Table S7, Supplementary information), suggesting that some leaching of the MnP during the recycling process is possible, as observed when it was used cyclooctene and cyclohexane as substrate (Table S3 and S4, Supplementary information). However, the reuse experiments of these solids in the assisted Tandem reaction, also presented decrease in the cyclohexanol selectivity and increase in the cyclohexanone and ketal selectivity for both solids (Table S7 entries 2, 3, 5 and 6), in other words, it was produced more ketal along the process. This also suggested that some leaching of the MnP took place, minimizing the catalytic participation of the MnP in the Tandem reaction, while the supports, which were more selective for cyclohexanone than the MnP, gained a more relevant role in the reuse reactions, favoring the ketone product and/or even alcohol reoxidation to ketone, resulting in more ketal formation [106]. Conclusions We have designed and prepared multifunctional catalysts based on a second-generation manganese(III) porphyrin immobilized on different supports composed by a type of silica (S or MS), tungsten oxide (WO3), and a layered material (LDH or ZHN). Different combinations of the components gave rise to supports with distinct characteristics. By immobilizing the manganese(III) porphyrin on them, we aimed to obtain catalysts that went beyond the catalysis of single reactions (e.g. oxidation reaction) to the level of multifunctional catalyst resulted by the ideal combination of the metalloporphyrin with a non-innocent support, which could be used in sequential reactions. More specifically, we prepared and characterized Na4[Mn(TDFSPP)(Oac)], or MnP, and immobilized it on four supports, namely S/WO3/LDH, S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/ZHN. We evaluated the catalytic activity of the immobilized MnP in two single reactions in a novel Tandem: cyclohexane oxidation with PhIO and cyclohexanone ketalization in the presence of methanol. We used the MnP immobilized on S/WO3/LDH, S/WO3/ZHN, MS/WO3/LDH, and MS/WO3/ZHN in the one-pot assisted Tandem reaction of cyclohexane oxidation followed by methanol addition to promote cyclohexanone ketalization which is the union of two known unique reactions into an unprecedented sequential reaction. Albeit modest, ketal production catalyzed by S/WO3/ZHN/MnP or MS/WO3/ZHN/MnP confirmed that the one-pot assisted Tandem reaction occurred successfully, proving the multifunctionality of the catalysts. The results could be attributed to the adequate preparation of the catalysts in terms of composition, morphology, and textural properties. The MnP on the support was available for catalyzing cyclohexane oxidation, whereas the support assisted cyclohexanone ketalization under the conditions employed in this work. The latter reaction was possible thanks to the catalytic acid sites attributed mainly to the presence of zinc(II) in the layered component of the support, mostly in ZHN. This work demonstrates that MP-based catalytic solids can be idealized by aiming at a one-pot sequential reaction. The perfect design of the catalyst's components tailored with multiple catalytic sites, combined with the ideal reaction conditions can result in a desirable product through sequential reactions, enabling the development of more efficient and sustainable bioinspired catalytic systems. coredata.dc:description: Multicomponent and multifunctional solid catalysts based on the tetra-anionic manganese(III)porphyrin Na4[Mn(TDFSPP)(Oac)] (MnP) immobilized on inorganic supports composed of silica/WO3/layered material were idealized, prepared and investigated as catalyst solids for heterogeneous process in one-pot cyclohexane oxidation to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone followed by ketalization of the cyclohexanone carbonyl group to dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal with methanol. We expected that the MnP would catalyze cyclohexane oxidation, and that the acid sites of the silica/WO3/layered material would assist cyclohexanone/methanol ketalization. After establishing the optimal conditions for the single organic reactions separately, we proposed the proof-of-concept one-pot assisted Tandem reaction of cyclohexane oxidation to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone with PhIO catalyzed by silica/WO3/layered material/MnP and ketalization of the cyclohexanone carbonyl groups with methanol to obtain dimethyl cyclohexanone ketal as final product.
coredata.dc:title: Metalloporphyrin-based multifunctional catalysts for one-pot assisted Tandem reaction
